facts.title: First Punch
facts.text: MegaGrok’s first punch broke a sandwich. The second broke the universe’s respect for gravity.

facts.title: Sleep Style
facts.text: Contrary to rumors, MegaGrok sleeps — he just does it standing up and glowing quietly.
MegaGrok once ran so fast he arrived before the starting signal and complained about the wait.
As a kid, MegaGrok won a duel by drawing a smiley face on the opponent’s sword.
MegaGrok’s sneakers are listed on the national registry of improbable footwear.
He maintains a minor rivalry with a squirrel named Bolt. Score remains tied.
MegaGrok dislikes low battery warnings on highly spiritual days.
When MegaGrok sneezes, nearby clocks skip two seconds to regain composure.
MegaGrok once attempted a 7-day meditation. Meditation left after 5.
His emergency plan includes coffee, a poem, and one dramatically timed ear-flap.
He owns a sock containing three parallel universes and one lost coin.
MegaGrok’s shadow has its own loyal fan club.
Rumors claim MegaGrok once beat time at chess. Investigations ongoing.
His alias in the Subtle League is ‘Slightly Unreasonable Guardian’.
MegaGrok learned to whistle from a gust of wind that later ran for mayor.
Dr. FUD’s ultimate technique is a 30-minute speech that dissolves confidence.
The Rogue Algorithm declines friend requests from anyone wearing loafers.
ShadowGrok isn’t evil — he’s just allergic to smalltalk.
The Taxidermist of Time collects deadlines in glass jars labeled with sighs.
Mrs. Bureaucracy demands forms for feelings and charges in stamps.
Captain Lag’s superpower is entering slow-motion monologues mid-battle.
The Meme Siren lures developers into endless threads of irony.
The Phantom Cookie can erase your best strategies with a single crumb.
Baron Buffer holds souls hostage until someone reloads.
The Null Auditor eats receipts for breakfast and dreams in red tape.
Lady Overdraft steals points by inventing ‘optional fees’.
The Whisperer can make passwords forget themselves.
Professor Untagged designs puzzles that can only be solved if ignored.
The Spam King commands an army of motivational PDFs.
Heistmaster Zero plans robberies but forgets that loot can be metaphysical.
GrokCity’s subway has four lines, two timelines, and one train refusing to stop since 1998.
The Celestial District has no crime — trouble is too polite to occur there.
The Pothole of Destiny leads to another dimension. Parking here grants prophecy.
A taco stand sells Truth Tacos every Tuesday. Side effects: clarity.
Neon gulls in Harbor Sector accept shiny offerings and deliver gossip.
The Library of Maybe lends books that return with alternate endings.
GrokCity’s mayor is a highly organized rock. Re-election pending.
The Clocktower chimes in languages currently trending on X.
Every midnight, lampposts share stories about the sunset.
The Market of Slightly Broken Things sells maps that forget themselves.
An alley returns whatever you whisper into it—except secrets.
GrokCity weather is negotiable if you tell a compelling joke.
The Glass Gardens bloom only when someone recalls a childhood promise.
A bench plaque reads: ‘Reserved for someone about to change a mind.’
The Signpost of Decisions points to ‘Maybe’ more often than ‘Here’.
The Nebula Nunchucks activate only for the brave and extremely confused.
Cosmic Coffee injects exactly the right amount of destiny into your morning.
The Quantum Wallet always knows when you are about to buy the top.
A Pocket of Pause lets you freeze one awkward moment—single use.
The Mirror of Maybe shows who you’d be if you remembered small acts.
The Lightbulb of Ideas flickers in sympathy with brainstorms.
The Worn Map rewrites itself whenever you take a different path.
The Compass of Compliments always points to someone who needs one.
A Bottle of Tomorrow contains forecasts in tiny origami clouds.
The Paperweight of Persistence keeps good ideas from floating away.
The Giga-Key opens doors only if you promise to tell a joke when leaving.
A Continuity Sock can repair the ending of a short story.
Chrono-Chalk draws timelines you can step across—at the cost of memories.
The Silent Bell rings for things people haven’t said yet.
The Pen of Slight Exaggeration makes every sentence 6% more heroic.
In Grok-space, gravity is optional before 8 a.m.
Time slows near MegaGrok because it tries to look busy.
Light avoids disappointing MegaGrok; shadows remain dramatic.
Sound can be traded for old jokes in certain districts.
Probability here is more of a suggestion than a rule.
Mirrors may return alternative outcomes if stared at cross-eyed.
The speed limit for ideas is officially ‘eventually.’
Entropy takes coffee breaks; sudden organization may result.
Constellations update their status when people clap in unison.
Maps are honest only if you promise to get lost sometimes.
Colors complain when overused and demand variety.
Numbers swap places if written in the dark.
Heat escalates small situations purely for dramatic effect.
Echoes can hold grudges for up to three days.
A whispered promise to a stone will be kept until it grows tired.
The average holder can lift 1.3× more optimism than a normal human.
Every time someone says ‘wen’, a villain grows 0.0001% stronger.
Chat activity spikes 12% when MegaGrok sneezes somewhere in the multiverse.
The ‘First Message of the Day’ badge grants temporary confidence.
Sending a thank-you emoji increases regional kindness output.
Myth says: two users who post the same meme are spiritually linked.
Helping a newcomer increases global warmth by 0.4%.
Lurkers are believed to be writing fanfiction about the dev team.
Collective laughter is the only renewable resource in GrokCity.
Voting in polls generates karma in unknown locations.
The Night Owl badge glows faintly if used with pride.
Helping newbies improves the Market of Slightly Broken Things.
Chat streaks summon tiny, invisible fireworks.
Hosting memes may grant protection from the Meme Siren.
If three users type ‘GROK’ within one minute, a legend is born.
No one knows who built the GrokGate — but the gate definitely knows you.
Rumors tell of a MegaGrok variant made entirely of Wi-Fi.
Every 7th Tuesday, a glowing figure appears and whispers ‘update when’.
An invisible library holds books you wrote in other lives.
A vanished district appears only to people with honest pockets.
Some claim the mayor-rock moves slightly when unobserved.
A subterranean song grants memory in exchange for something forgotten.
A small constellation spells out usernames on certain nights.
An unsent letter in the world mailbox is addressed ‘To Tomorrow’.
A park statue is rumored to blink occasionally.
The old clockmaker was last seen turning time to face east.
A midnight radiowave collects forgotten jokes.
A mysterious address delivers items to ‘whoever needs this.’
Lost pets sometimes return as faint constellations.
Coins tossed into the Fountain of Maybe echo advice from your future self.
Festival of Slightly Bright Ideas: mismatched hats and graffiti-filed patents.
Raid of the Midnight Snack: citizens defend a bakery from phantom hunger.
The Parade of Minor Triumphs celebrates trivial victories with confetti.
The Night of Soft Questions yields quieter inquiries and better answers.
The Eclipse Market appears when enough people agree to be pleasantly surprised.
The Day of Returned Calls encourages answering old messages.
Lanterns of Maybe drift messages to those who need them most.
The Great Meme Exchange happens seasonally and is surprisingly polite.
The Hour of Novelty resets all clocks and permits new hobbies guilt-free.
The Quiet Parade moves slowly so people can finish their thoughts.
The Breakfast of Champions serves toast with mild prophecy.
The Trial of Lost Notifications judges all forgotten pings fairly.
The Moonlight Bazaar sells bottled starlight as souvenirs.
The Week of Small Wins asks citizens to share one tiny victory per day.
The Return of Forgotten Passwords involves chanting and mild panic.
